title: Prototyping Board with LED and Potentiometers

description.text:
This is a proto-board (830 point solderless Bread Board) holder with a back board to hold LED's, potentiometers and buttons. The design was born out of the frustration with prototyping common components and having wires everywhere. This board is intended to help clean up some of the clutter in prototyping and help provide a more stable prototyping environment.

Additionally this was my first attempt at a snap fit latch and a vehicle to work with multi-component assemblies. The latch needed a little shaving and ended up being too weak so i will need to work on that some more but it does help locate the LED diffuser.

Some of the clearances are pretty tight and may need a little work with the X-acto knife.
I used OnShape to put the model together

author: Willir42

description.text:
When I saw another towel spike here on thingiverse, I thought that it was not taking advantage of the strong points of the printing process, making it likely to fracture when driving it in to the ground. I made this one to print flat on the bed, making it much stronger and less prone to break when in use.   
I have this design printing right now, and will post a photo once it's done.  
I also designed one that would double as a vampire stake, which is probably not optimal, but I thought I'd include it anyway (spike2). Enjoy!   
Follow me for more useful designs.

It's a very fat ring that I have designed for my ring fingers, I have one in each hand. I recommend to edit the FreeCAD file to fit the ring to your fingers. You can print the ring in resin and with a silicon mould create a wax mould (or more) and cast it in your favourite metal.

Es un anillo muy gordo que he diseñado para mis dedos anulares. Tengo uno en cada mano. Recomiendo editar el fichero de FreeCAD para ajustar el anillo a tus dedos. Puedes imprimir el anillo en resina, y con un molde de silicona sacar uno (o más) de cera para fundir en tu metal favorito.

description.text:
this is a simple spinner with 5 leds that shows a a word when you spin it. i use 1x attiny85, 5 x leds, 5 x 65 ohms resistors, 1 x switch and 1 x 3 volt botton batery. i add the schematichs, the pcb and the program.

video: https://youtu.be/fRVIec4Avaw

this is the arduino program:

void displayLine(int line)
{
int myline;
myline = line;
if (myline>=16) {digitalWrite(LED1, HIGH); myline-=16;} else {digitalWrite(LED1, LOW);}
if (myline>=8) {digitalWrite(LED2, HIGH); myline-=8;} else {digitalWrite(LED2, LOW);}
if (myline>=4) {digitalWrite(LED3, HIGH); myline-=4;} else {digitalWrite(LED3, LOW);}
if (myline>=2) {digitalWrite(LED4, HIGH); myline-=2;} else {digitalWrite(LED4, LOW);}
if (myline>=1) {digitalWrite(LED5, HIGH); myline-=1;} else {digitalWrite(LED5, LOW);}
}

void displayChar(char c)
{
if (c == 'a'){for (int i = 0; i <5; i++){displayLine(a[i]);delay(delayTime);}displayLine(0);}
if (c == 'b'){for (int i = 0; i <5; i++){displayLine(b[i]);delay(delayTime);}displayLine(0);}

if (c == '.'){for (int i = 0; i <5; i++){displayLine(eos[i]);delay(delayTime);}displayLine(0);}
delay(charBreak);
}

void displayString(char* s)
{
for (int i = 0; i<=strlen(s); i++)
{
displayChar(s[i]);
}
}

void loop()
{
displayString(" hola mundo ");
}

title: Eachine VR D2 & D2 PRO goggles viewfinder extension

description.text:
I bought the D2 Pro just to find out that I cannot see clearly in them, even though I have good sight.
So I wanted to make some non intrusive way of adding focal length.
Designed it, printed, than added some 1mm foam inside, and in the front.
Some 5 mm foam on the back for my face.
Than I drilled 4 m3 holes in both goggles and the extension.
I also changed the curvature of the face-side to fit better on my face.
If any questions - just ask. Cheers

description.text:
This Stanley knife holder, is a 'one print' piece where the blade is placed into the model halfway into the print. After watching numerous 3d printing videos on youtube, I thought I should investigate placing items inside prints. That is what I did.

When printing you start the print and just before it starts printing the layers on-top of the blade, pause the print, place the blade inside and carry on printing. This technique gives you a great finish and allows for a part which requires no assembly whatsoever.

The blade I used for this project was a Stanley Blade, Part No. 11-912 -
http://www.stanleytools.com/products/hand-tools/knives-blades/replacement-blades/5-pk-1992-heavyduty-utility-blades/11-921

Pause the print when it gets to 2.75mm. In Cura, you can do this by going to Extensions -> Post Processing -> Modify G-Code. This gives you the option to pause at a certain height.
This drawing represents the Stanley blade I worked off of in order to get the measurements correct. This drawing was completed by myself.

author: jousis

description.text:
Im sorry or all of the reading, but here's my hotend. My hotend is built from a piece of oak dowel rod that I had laying around, a 3mm OD, 2mm ID ptfe tube that I got on ebay for really cheap, a piece of a heatsink from a power supply (solid aluminum block), a 1 inch piece of a 6mm bolt with a 3mm hole drilled through it, and a welding MIG tip. Most of this can be found in your garage, the trash, or at walmart, lol. The rest of what you need is just generic hotend parts from wherever you normally get them. As Ive shown in the drawings, the thermal break is 32mm long with a 2mm hole drilled longways through it. Then drill a hole 3mm though it till 3mm from the end, and a 5mm hole 14mm into the piece of wood so it matches the drawing above, then just use a drill bit and turn it with your fingers to taper off the top. I then used my 1/4th inch hole cleaner tool, but you can just use a 1/4th inch or 6mm die to cut threads into the dowel rod so it fits in well. The heater block is just a 10mmx20mmx16.5mm aluminum block that was cut from the heatsink with a 6mm hole drilled through the side/end for the heater element, a threaded m6 or 1/4th inch hole, and a 3mm hole, threaded for a screw in thermistor, but you can just put the thermistor in the hole instead. The metal tube that connects the heater block and everything together, that's just a 1/4th inch(6mm) stainless steel bolt that I cut off the head so it's just a hollow bolt with a 3mm 1/8th inch hole through the middle of it. It's around a 1 inch (25.4mm) long. I also put a simple washer and a nut on the bolt, then screwed it in so it locked everything tight against the thermal break(oak piece) The tip is threaded and the original threads of the MIG tip is cut off, the threads of the tip will go 5mm(half way into the heater block) and stick out around 7.5mm, just use a hammer and file to smooth down the nozzle like you see in wildseyed's hotend. I drilled mine 2mm till almost 1mm from the end of the tip, almost to the very tip of the nozzle. Then I drilled 3mm into around 2mm from the opening so it goes from 3mm hole, to 2mm hole, then the end of the nozzle. Lastly, you need to run the 3mm OD, 2mm ID ptfe tubing as far as it will go into the hollow bolt and thermal break, then cut it off a hair over 2mm from the end of the bolt so it overhangs just slightly. This is so that when you put it together, it'll self seal itself up and wont leak. I put the nozzle in first and tightened it up, then put the bolt attached inside of the oak rod in, and tighten it up, it'll seal it up. Just use some PTFE plumbers tape on the threads going into the heater block so you never have to worry about any leaks. Ive only used this hotend with PLA, and it works perfectly with that, but I cant see any issues why it wouldnt work with ABS also. Ive been using this hotend on my homemade prusa i2, and it's performed perfectly since it's been built. Before anyone asks about max temps and such, truth is, Im not sure what it would be but probably is around 240s or so due to the ptfe in it. EDIT: here's a video of the printer running with the hotend:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c5UHJzLdNJk

comments.text: Please dont laugh too hard at this, I honestly made it out of a bet that I couldnt make a hotend out of anything but junk laying around the house/garage, but supprisingly, it works as well as my ubis hotend in my printrbot jr. Only real difference is the nozzle end is a little bit bigger than the nozzle in the ubis hotend, but both perform just as well.

As shown on the last picture, the wooden strips angles must be chamfered by 15mm, using a file or a sharp knife. Never force the wood into the printed parts or the layers will split from each other. Simply sand the wood if needed.

I used beechwood and matte black paint.

title: IKEA LILLABO to BRIO train track connector

description.text:
The LILLABO toy train tracks have plastic connectors that are designed to be compatible with BRIO tracks. However, the fit is very tight and thus LILLABO tracks might not be compatible with all third-party (cheapo) tracks out there.
This connector is 2mm longer than the original, thus allowing tracks to be compatible with virtually any wooden train set. As a drawback, connections will be looser. The length can however be easily customized to achieve what you want.

The design is fully adjustable and can be customized to fit your needs. Adjust the value of the 'stud_length' variable in the SCAD file to control the length of the connector (the original IKEA piece is 20mm). Or use the Customizer to do that.   
The four little nods on the larger end of the connector are to secure it firmly in the track. Depending on your fabrication method, you might need to adjust the nods so that the connector can be easily sled into the track yet remain firmly in place. The 'nod_recess' variable indicates how deep the nods are recessed in the surface. The lower the amount, the more the nods will stick out. Try it out!  
I used 3D printing to make these, but they could also be cut out of wood or MDF with a laser or router. Enjoy!

comments.text: I made one, but its too short to fit the tracks together.  I can't scale it larger, as the four anti-slip bumps are already too tight.
comments.author: jlambe15

comments.text: Hi and thanks for the feedback. I've found that the stud length had to be adapted depending on the track brand. Have you tried opening the file in the Customizer (see option just above the Download button) and play with the "Stud length" value? If you increase this number, you should get a longer connector, without changing any of the other dimensions.

comments.text: The casting is pictured sitting in a pile of broken pieces of the mold.  The mold was made from 20 minute drywall joint compound.  Make sure to get "setting type",  the stuff which comes as a powder.  A 20lb bag is less than $10.  It works well enough that you can see the defects in the print which led me to experiment with it.
comments.author: Shapespeare

comments.text: I think you will have trouble burning your mold out with a direct flame.  I heat my molds in a digitally controlled kiln which is set to ramp up to 1400F with stops along the way to let the investment dry out slowly.  The idea is to soak the mold at a high temp to insure that all the plastic has melted or burned out.  I am left with a very little residue which might be non flammable pigments or something like that (I should try clear ABS).  If you can't get a good soak it will be hard to get the mold clean.
comments.author: Shapespeare

comments.text: I continually hear that electric kilns are the best option. Thanks for the info, I've already learned the hard way by burning my heel with aluminum after forgetting to cook my plaster mold. I joined the meetup group! One of these thursdays I'll try to come by the workshop and learn something new. One last question- The material you broke your mold from; is that a plaster?
comments.author: Shapespeare

comments.text: I've had a hard time burning PLA out of plaster or sand. It's very clutchy in its liquid goo state and somehow under a large propane flame for 15 minutes on full blast it still seems to sit in the cracks and corners. I poured hot aluminum onto a mold I didn't thoroughly burn all the way but because I got impatient.  I poured and the aluminum sputtered all over around my setup! Sp looking back on it I just want to spread the word it was a bit scary but if you already know how to burn it all the way out, let me know how your casts go!
comments.author: lordkylo

description.text: Butterfly #2

i recently fell in love with Perry T.'s 4d staunton chess set, and had to make one. the pieces are beautiful and the board is really sexy. But, i wanted the board to feel more 'one piece' color wise, and saw an opportunity to make an improvement!

this remix only includes the new squares, for the rest of the pieces you'll need to go to Perry T.'s page: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40605/

importing these into simplify3d, you can just set Square Two Color 1's z height to 0 to make these line up, or select both models and then edit, align selected model origins. i tried to make this one piece and then just separate the mesh in simplify to make things easier, but for some reason it couldn't detect two separate models...

obviously you'll need a two color printer for this. if you have simplify3d, leverage that dual extrusion wizard!

author: energy29uk

print_settings.Notes:: The model was designed for printing on an Ultimaker 3 sized bed, if you need to print it on a smaller bed you can use mesh mixer to slice it up into smaller pieces. Keep in mind structural integrity when doing this.

description.text: Scathach's spear from FFXIV, used for a cosplay of said boss from Final Fantasy XIV.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.06mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Model should be fine with 0.1mm or even 0.2mm printer resolution. I did 0.06mm and it was probably overkill. Otherwise, this model is designed to be printed without supports and used the default Ultimaker 3 settings.

The model was designed for printing on an Ultimaker 3 sized bed, if you need to print it on a smaller bed you can use mesh mixer to slice it up into smaller pieces. Keep in mind structural integrity when doing this.

Step 1

Glue the mirrored halves together, making sure to keep the parts lined up. I recommend 5-minute cure epoxy, but depending on your material you may want to do something different.

Step 2

Clean up the pin holes by using a drill with 1/8 inch and 1/4 inch bits.

Step 3

Take a wooden dowel, cut it to size for scaling the prop, and drill a 1/4 inch hole in the center of each end. Optional: Cut the dowel in half and drill some additional holes for adding a hanger bolt and e-nut wood insert hexagonal screw so you can take the spear apart for travel. The hanger bolt and nut can be hard to find, but the clerks at your local hardware store can help you get what you need.

Step 4

Coating the pins in epoxy, insert them into the pieces, then put the pieces together.

Step 5

Using bondo or wood filler, fill in the cracks between pieces.

Step 6

Prepare the surface with some combination of sanding, filler primer, XTC-3D, and did I mention sanding?

Step 7

Paint it! You will want to do a ton of masking with painter's tape. My one regret with this model is that I didn't separate out the pieces based on how it was to be painted, which means a lot of time will be spent masking with painter's tape.

I started off doing the blue before moving to the metallic parts, but how you paint it is largely up to you.

title: AnyCubic i3 Mega E3D V6 Hotend Upgrade Kit

description.text:
This kit contains three parts used to upgrade the standard extruder on the AnyCubic i3 Mega (also called Omega i3) to the official E3D V6 hotend.

The parts included are:

  • Bowden Support -> Supports the tube connection to the hotend
  • Left Cover -> Used to attached the original part cooling fan
  • Adapter ring -> Connects to the top of the hotend and ensures the height of the upgrade places the nozzle at the same height as the original hotend

Print all parts at 0.2mm and without supports or rafts.

The following video is a guided tutorial of the full installation process:
Installation Video

My Simplify3D profile created for the AnyCubic i3 Mega that has been upgraded with both the Titan extruder and the E3D V6 hotend can be be downloaded from:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/yo4w8ik8nuzrsf8/Omega%20i3%20E3D%20V6.fff?dl=0

You will need the following parts from E3D online to complete the full upgrade:

  • E3D V6 Hotend with 1.75mm, Bowden, 12V

And if you want to use my profile you will also need the following:

  • Titan Extruder with 1.75mm Bowden, Standard, Mounting Bracket

The Amiga Raspberry Pi Case pictured above was printed on the upgraded AnyCubic i3 Mega and shows what incredible quality the printer is capable of producing.

Printer:

AnyCubic i3 Mega

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

This is a dual picatinny rail mount for the Crosman 2240.

The model requires a little bit of sanding to make a snug fit. I used some 400 grit sandpaper wrapped around a rod and slightly sanded the inside of both holes.

I also added four holes for brass M3 inserts. These can be melted in with a soldering iron. And I screwed in four grub screws.
It may not be necessary when you already have a very tight fit.

The model is printed in PLA/PHA. No support material is needed.

description.text: Geared hearts fascinate me (perhaps because I was born on Valentines day?). I'm unsure as to who created the first one (sorry for being unable to credit the original creator) as I was unaware that geared hearts had been around for a while. For example, I found this 2008 video of a paper hand cranked geared heart http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=70dKZjP4NOo and was intrigued. And then I found emmett's Thingiverse Featured http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:243278 and, well, here it goes. Inspired by the paper hand cranked geared heart video, and emmett's brilliant geared heart design, yet having too little time to create one entirely on my own, I incorporated emmett's geared heart into this design to create my hand cranked PLA version of the hand cranked paper geared heart. The video of my version is at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6V-IYuWghAQ. And if you don't like cranking the heart by hand, then a motorized version is at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:255280. Designed using Sketchup 8, and printed in PLA on a Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" settings. UPDATES: 1) Added "Heart Base 1-2.stl" to work with emmett's "HeartGears1-2.stl". Has not been tested yet, printer be warned!

Study "Assembly.skp".  
Print emmett's geared heart "HeartGears2-3.stl".  As of update 1, you can also print emmett's geared heart "HearGears1-2.stl", but it has not been tested.  The bottom and center pieces are not used, nor is one of the clips, so if you can edit the .stl file and delete these components, you can save print time and PLA.  
Print "Heart Center.stl", then using emmett's instructions, assemble the heart onto "Heart Center.stl" noting again that the bottom piece and clip are not used.  
Print the remaining parts and assemble as per "Assembly.skp" except for "Heart Center Drill Motor.stl".  Also note I printed "Heart Base.stl"(or "Heart Base 1-2.stl" for emmett's "HeartGears1-2.stl", but not tested)" in white for the first 4mm height to match the color of "Base.stl", then switched to red for the remainder of the print.  If you use Sailfish firmware on your Replicator 2, you can program the print to pause at 4.2mm while the print is in progress and allow a change in filament color.  
If you find your heart is too tight, then disassemble it, and reassemble it using "Heart Center Drill Motor.stl" through "Heart Base.stl".  Chuck the shaft of "Heart Center Drill Motor.stl" into a hand drill, and while holding onto "Heart Base.stl", spin the assembly forward and backward at low to moderate speeds until it loosens up.  Once loosened, disassemble and reassemble using "Heart Center.stl".  Even if you do not wish to build this thing, you can loosen up your emmett heart using this technique.  
With emmett's "HeartGears2-3.stl" gear ratio and the gear ratio of "Gear Main.stl" to "Gear Handle.stl", 5 turns of the handle will completely cycle the heart from start to finish.  
Hope you like it.

comments.text: Just wanted to update--everything worked great.  I did add a washer above the large gear, and beside the small gear to help eliminate movement and keep them in contact.  I wish I was smart enough to just make the washers about 2mm thicker to help gear mesh, but maybe someday I'll figure that out.  I'm still learning regarding 3d modeling.  I'm a CNC programmer and drafter, but my line of work RARELY requires 3D design.  That's why I bought my printer, so that I could be forced to learn.    UNFORTUNATELY, after making my first geared heart, now all my friends want one.

Printed all with Makerware on a Makerbot Rep2 with default settings -- except when I printed the gears and box I printed with 100% fill so they would be sturdier.  It's disappointing, but I'm still going to try and figure out a way to get it to work.

title: Button Battery Adapter - AG-3 to AG-13

description.text:

title: Pill cutter enhanced to cut thirds...

description.text: I really only modified the Pill Holder itself.  My wife is always having me cut a particular medication of hers into a 1/3rd and 2/3rds section to allow her to take 2/3rds of a dose.  I found the original Pill Cutter here on Thingiverse and gave a lot of thought as to how I could modify it.  As I was making the changes I considered taking it several steps further and add relief ridges for different size pills as well as cutting pills into 3rds.  The actual shape should provide a cut that is approximately a 3rd cut.  I haven't printed it yet, but hoping to this weekend.  I'll add a picture of the final product when it's done.

comments.text: Sorry for the lack of updates for this thing. I've printed this version as well as 2 updated versions and I still haven't quite worked out the kinks.  The blade holder is fine, however, the pill holder still needs some work.  I will provide updated files when I have it completed.

title: dyson adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
hey guys,

i found lots of dyson adapters in here, but in most cases somebody wrote, they wouldn't fit. so i decided to come up with my own, which was quicker than try and fail in the end.

i have a dc29 and no idea, how interchangeable that is to other dysons. but on my dc29 it fits fine.

i wanted to have an adapter to a flexible hose with a very small aperture, which fits most other vacuum cleaners - just not the dyson. as this part has a somewhat strange universal-kind adapter, I wanted the dyson-half of the adapter only to build my own other end, but i only found complete adapters.

so here i give you both parts - the dyson-only-half for you to build whatever you need on the other side yourself, and my adapter to this somehow universal thing, of which i unfortunately don't know the name.

oh, forgot one thing. in contrast to the original dyson parts, this one can turn around - i think it's an advantage - if you don't like it, you need to put little stoppers into the nut.

print_settings.Notes:: There shouldn't be any need for any support material, but it wouldn't hurt to add it underneath the IO cutouts and screw recesses on the bottom. To place a Raspberry Pi inside the console, you'll need four M2,5 screws at 5mm long, and to attach the bottom to the top you'll need three M3 screws at 16-20mm long as well. Everything has been modeled so you can self tap by pressing in firmly when initially putting in the screw, but if the M3 screws are difficult, there's ample room to use a tap.

title: 2040 2020 aluminium profile Anet AM8 led holder

description.text:
Simple LED holder for 2040 or 2020 aluminium profiles. You will need a 1mm by 20mm piece of aluminium sheet to act as holder.

Also, this piece of aluminium is used as heat bridge between LED and the profile. That's why no additional heatsinks are necessary. Some heat-paste between LED and aluminium sheet is recommended.

Model designed with quite high tolerances to tight-fit.

LEDs used: https://www.banggood.com/10W-Warm-Pure-White-High-Brightest-Save-Power-LED-Light-Lamp-p-88169.html

I'm running the LED from 9,5V not to overheat it. Not mounted, the aluminium sheet tops 35*C.

Printed from standard PLA. For better heat resistance I would recommend PET or ABS.

remixed_from.author: SwiftyTheFox
remixed_from.title: Bases with Lip for Tabletop / Wargaming

title: Wargaming Round Lipped bases for Mantic Miniatures and similar, 25mm and 20mm

description.text:
Over the years of collecting wargaming miniatures, I have come to dislike square bases. After I was introduced to the round lipped base some years ago, I have preferred that style to other styles of bases.

I have a load of older Mantic fantasy miniatures with little 15mm flat round integral bases, and mounting these on regular square 20mm to rank up means both having to use square bases that I do not like the look of, and needing to take alot of care when ranking up so the fit next to each other on the movement tray. Round 20mm with 15mm recess not being available as far as I have seen.

My solution to this is to make my own bases.

Here is a 25mm and a 20mm round base with chamfered edges, that have a recess to fit the smaller mantic integral base.

So now I have have my preferred round lipped style of base, with the official footprint-sized rankability for my Mantic troops for Kings of War.

Bonus effect; The round bases make the minis much easier to rank up, just rotate a little here and there to make them fit better next to one another.

It can be a pain to replace a G4 halogen bulb, especially if you follow the recommendation not to touch the glass by hand. This little tool can help you.

There are no special requirements for the printing. It can be difficult to get the thin wall to look nice, but in most cases it is not important for function of the tool.

I have printed mine in PLA on a DaVinci Jr.

Most bulbs have a diameter around 8 mm, but some are thicker. I have added a “fat” version for those.

As it is only 12 volt, you can leave power on when you fit the new bulb. But as the plastic cannot resist the heat from the bulb for longer time, you have to be fast and remove the tool as soon the bulb is in. If you have to search for the right position of the bulb, you should press the bulb in as soon as you see the first blink of light, and remove the tool just as fast.

title: Stick format hardcase cover for 2S lipos.

description.text:
A hardcase cover for using lipo batteries in cars that have battery compartments designed for 7,2V ni-mh stick packs. It protects the battery from crash damage and also protects the edges of the pack from damage when used in a car with a rounded battery mounting frame, like many Tamiya cars or old cars.

It is specifically designed for a 2S 3300 mAh battery with the dimensions 134 x 42.4 mm x 14.8 mm. Any pack that is equal to or smaller than all these dimensions will fit.

Stickcover01 has the text 3300 mAh on it.
Stickcover02 does not have the text 3300 mAh on it.

Notes:

Two perimeters and very low infill is recommended to keep the weight down while keeping the shell sufficiently strong.

Print in the orientation they open, standing on the end.

I have updated this thing to remove the full positioning rail in the center. When using T-nuts, they made contact with the rail and caused issues.

I wanted something fast and easy to print that would hold a Pi 2/3 to the extrusion using standard M4 T-nuts. Used supports touching the build plate to provide support. Designed to hold standard M2.5 nuts on the back side to hold the Pi in place. M4X8 button head fasteners are used to hold the mount to the rail (10mm is too long and will contact the extrusion).

I might modify it to allow access to the SD card, but I believe the spacers designed into the mount should allow enough access to get the card in and out.

title: Remix of Drive Bay Adapter V4 (3.5" to 2x2.5") by TheGoatPuncher (less plastic)

description.text:
The Drive Bay Adapter V4 (3.5" to 2x2.5") by TheGoatPuncher is exactly what I was looking for. I just wanted a version with less plastic, mainly to reduce the print time, but also because it might improve cooling. OpenSCAD did not like the original STL file [ERROR: CGAL error in CGAL_Nef_polyhedron3(): CGAL ERROR: assertion violation!] so I ran it through the Netfabb online service.

I you want to print my version you only need tv-2456254_DriveBayAdapter.3.5.V4_mod.stl.

If you want to perform additional changes, you can get tv-2456254_DriveBayAdapter.3.5.V4_fixed.stl (the STL from TheGoatPuncher post-processed by Netfabb) and tv-2456254_DriveBayAdapter.3.5.V4_mod.scad (the OpenSCAD file).

description.text: Directional rotating pulley for filament. It is positioned upside down on the printer frame and the filament is passed over this pulley. This ensures good feeding of the filament. Filamet can be placed behind the printer on the desk and does not burden the printer frame. The rotating head follows the printhead.

Printer:

Tronxy P802MA

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

swivel joint:
On the swivel joint, the bottom part with a 20 mm screw is firmly attached to the nut on the lower part. Two slides are slid along the sliding profile against each other.
Replace the top and fit the washer.
There is one nut on the bolt, it must not be tightened too tightly and the second nut nut is added to it, thus creating a swivel joint.

pulley:
Inside the upper part, the pulley is separated from each side by a single washer so as to ensure that the pulley is secured in the middle. A 30mm bolt is used. Do not stretch the power tightly. Another counter matrix may be used, but it is not normally needed.

Upper partition:
Attached directly to the material with a 12mm screw. Do not stretch the power tightly.
The squeegee is then inserted into the cut-out on the other side and holds itself in the base. It is possible to attach it with another 12mm screw.

Pulley:
It uses a 12mm diameter 30mm roller that is glued from two identical parts. He must turn slightly on the axis.

Finally, after assembly, lightly lubricate with petrolatum in spray.

Put it best on the middle of the printer, or use it anywhere else where the material is 7 mm thick.
Finally, after assembly, lightly lubricate with petrolatum in spray.
The design is created in FreeCAD.

author: stanicio

title: To Print Or Not To Print - Shakespeare at Leicester Square in London

description.text:
If you're on Thingiverse, you know already that, "To print or not to print..." THAT is the question!
This is a remix of Shakespeare at Leicester Square, London from the Scan the World archive at MyMiniFactory.com. It was just something we felt that the 3D printing community needed. Admittedly, we did this a while back and have been bad about getting around to publishing the share-alike version of the remix, as the license it was published under compels. But here it is, nonetheless. We love him.
We altered quite a few things on it (most notably the scroll) from his tassels and collar to his scroll finger and right heel, but as mentioned, it's been a while. If you're interested, please feel free to download the original and go over it. ;) https://www.myminifactory.com/object/william-shakespeare-at-leicester-square-london-4346
We have also made a version with the original scroll writing that says "THERE IS NO DARKNESS BUT IGNORANCE" and will get it posted shortly.
Sculpted by Giovanni Fontana after an original by Peter Scheemakers, the one in Leicester Square has formed the centerpiece of the Gardens there in London since 1874. Clearly, this object is in the Public Domain.

If you're printing this on an FDM printer, it probably goes without saying, but you'll need to be extraordinarily careful removing his supports. I created the supports by hand in Meshmixer at the time. Go slowly. Lots of patience. Super result.

remixed_from.author: Latzenpratz
remixed_from.title: Ikea Lack raiser and window holder

title: IKEA Lack Raiser with placing main board externally

description.text:
With my design the printing area is in the isolated warm box (when printing with PLA 190°C/60°C, the internal temperature keeps at 37-38°C), while all electronics (ZRIB motherboard, AC/DC converters, OrangePiZero) are in the external environment (21°C).

Modifications compared to other Lack raisers:

  1. I use no door hinges. Instead of that I use magnets. As benefit - I can easily take away whole window. As result I have access to the printer from 3 sides (one side is permanently closed, see below). Strong cylindrical magnets are glued into holes drilled in the plexiglass plates. Magnets hold plates perfectly.
  2. Each raiser was splitted into two parts: top (5mm) and bottom (95mm).
  3. Designed to move all electronics parts outside of the warm box (to avoid overheating). To achieve that, one plexiglass plate is permanently fixed (right one). All electronics are placed on this plate from external side (simply drilled holes in the plate and screwed all the stuff directly to the plate). For child-protection reasons, placed another sheet of plexiglass over the electronics (not full sized - there are huge ventilation holes on top and bottom). The displays (printer's LCD, thermometer, current meter), and buttons are placed on the external sheet.
  4. also designed handles for glasses and connectors (for holding of second sheet with displays).

Printer:

Zonestart 802QR2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

comments.text: Do you have a closeup of how the magnets are attached? The holes in the components look like they're designed to hold some bolts. Also can I just print 4 of LackRaiser_bottom_1 if I don't want to use 2 panes to put the electronics? I plan on putting the electronics on top of the table.
comments.author: syntaxerr0r

comments.text: Magnets are embedded into glass-panels - drilled 3mm-depth holes in 4mm thick glass, so magnets are completely glued-in and don't raise from surface. And on printed parts I have only screws with flat heads. See attachments.

title: Logitech C310 Wall Mount v2 (with Pi Shelf) - for MotionEye

description.text:
Original v1 here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2461242
Raspberry Pi case used: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1015706

I put together a baby cam with a Raspberry Pi 3 and a Logitech C310. The previous solution had a lot of visible wires and had the added risk of my wife spilling water into the Anker USB hub. My son since moved rooms, so that was a good excuse to quickly design a better mount.

The distance between the front and the hole fits the Logitech C310 webcam. It sits at a 30* angle looking right. One screw hole mounts it to the wall. This is very specific to my solution but maybe one of you could make use of it too.

Note: The camera wire was crazy long and needed to be shortened. The process is easy enough if you have some heat shrink and a soldering iron laying around. TIP: Cut the data and power wires to different lengths before soldering. It'll prevent a giant knuckle in the middle of the cable.

This is an add-on accessory for the totally awesome Vorpal Combat Hexapod, If you haven't seen that yet, then this thing won't make sense, so visit there first:

  • Thing 2513566: Vorpal Combat Hexapod

I made this all open source and respectfully ask you to consider supporting the project. We successfully funded on Kickstarter with hundreds of kits sold, and now we have our own store. We have more than just the Hexapod electronics, we have all kinds of things useful for small robotics and other projects:
Vorpal Robotics Store with Hexapod Kits

  • IMPORTANT: If you opt-in to receive our store monthly newsletters you'll automatically be enrolled in a monthly prize drawing, first prize is a $100 store credit and there are lots of other smaller prizes too! Sign up for newsletters here:
  • Vorpal Store Opt-in for Prize Drawing

Why do I need this for the Hexapod?

These are game pieces for the "Joust" game, played with two Vorpal Combat Hexapods.

Joust Game Video

The long thing is called the Lance. This attaches to the robot's accessory port in front of the robot. The little thing is the "rider". Magnets make the rider stick to the lance. There are two positions for the rider, front and back. The front position (farthest away from the robot) makes the game much easier for novices. You may also give "odds" to a novice player by putting your rider in front and letting theirs be in the back.

There are two different Lance variations. The curved version might be a little easier to use for some players. To be fair both players should have the same kind of lance.

For complete game rules see the Games and Activities Page on our website.

Installing the Magnets

Each design has a recepticle for a 10mm diameter by 3mm thick magnet. The magnet should be installed with the South pole exposed. In our kits, north pole is marked with a dimple. Magnets on the robot should have dimple showing, magnets on accessories that stick to the robot should have dimples hidden. Pretty easy.

The magnets, if they are the correct size, snap in. You may be able to do this with your fingrs, or you may need to gently use piiers to force them in that last little bit. But for me at least, they never fall out. If they fall out for you I'm sure a drop of superglue or hot glue will solve the problem.

Work in progress Working on a bowden conversion for the 2014 model of printrbot simple. This mod will take the extruder motor weight off of the Y axis and allow for faster, less shaky prints. The tip of the ubi hot end should be in the same position as before, so the existing fan shroud will still work. Besides the printed parts, you'll need about $12 in parts ( I got mine from amazon ), some machine screws and some m3 bolts and nuts ( I used some leftover from my printrbot ). Links for the parts on the instructions page. Feel free to contribute. Update - 2-21-14 New version of the hot end mount. Fixed some minor fitment issues and lowered the height to reduce the open gap above the hot end. Update - 2-25-14 First successful print using bowden style print. STLs and SKP files added. Note: Design of the motor mount will differ from the pictures until I can print the new version. ( The files available here are the new version ) Update - 3-2-14 So it seems that the aluminum extruder just can't provide the torque required to support bowden. I'm currently researching some alternatives to easily convert the aluminum bowden to a geared drive. Update - 4-11-14 I've recently found out that my hotend was damaged, causing the torque issues with my first attempt. A few people have reported the extruder working just fine for them, so this mod should be good to go. As soon as I get back to this project, I'll update the plate to Include some braces and vents to account for the rising heat from the extruder to prevent it from drooping over time. If anyone else wants to take a stab at that, please feel free.

Recommend printing this at a .3mm layer height with a 25% infill. No support material is required. Screws:
I'm using 2x 1 1/4in machine screws. They have an outer thread size of 4mm. Not sure of the exact type of screw, as it was from my extra screw pile. Amazon links:
2x Push-to-connect fittings: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004M8T28M
PTFE Teflon tubing ( 2mm ID / 4mm OD ): http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00C45208O

description.text:
Each block has the degrees angle printed within the block. Place the guide on your sharpening stone face up so you can read the numbers then place your knife on top. That is the angle at which you will sharpen your knife. This is meant as a guide and isn't meant to be on the stone while sharpening.

Most Japanese knives come from the factory sharpened at 17 degrees. Most knives for the European/North-American market are sharpened at 19-29 degrees. Outdoors/camping knives can hold their edge longer when sharpened to 22.5 degrees.

Introduction

Microcentrifuges are an essential piece of equipment in any biomedical laboratory. However, biomedical equipment like this is generally too expensive for most hobbyists to afford, so I developed this centrifuge to help lower the cost of a proper microcentrifuge.

What is a Microcentrifuge?

"Laboratory Centrifuge (Wikipedia)
A microcentrifuge is a device that spins samples at very high RPM in order to separate and purify materials in the samples. A common use for a microcentrifuge is Differential Centrifugation, which is used to separate organelles and nucleic acids(such as DNA) from cell samples. High quality, reliable microcentrifuge prices start from $1,000, and entry-level microcentrifuges cost around $300-$700. This is way too expensive for many hobbyists and other people, so I set off to develop my own open source microcentrifuge."

Impact of this project

This project is aimed towards biohacking communities, underpriveleged schools, and underfunded hospitals that cannot afford proper equipment. I hope this project will be useful to many, and can open up opportunities in areas that cannot provide them otherwise.

Instructions

Check out my project page on hackster.io:
https://www.hackster.io/kemfic/developing-a-low-cost-microcentrifuge-using-e-waste-04b525

description.text: Parts to fit a 150mm x 105mm x 55mm project box with a Raspberry Pi and Suptronics X400 DAC/Amp inside.

Notes:

These parts are to fit a 150mmx105mmx55mm aluminium project box (such as here
http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Aluminum-Box-Enclosure-Case-desktop-DIY-55mm-2-16-H-X105mm-4-14-W-X150mm-5/32342220019.html) with a Raspberry Pi with Suptronics X400 DAC/amp module (http://www.suptronics.com/xseries/x400.html)

The 'bottom' prints a plate that engages the grooves of the project box and provides mount points for the Raspberry Pi.

The 'front' replaces the aluminium plate at the front of the project box and has holes for the X400 volume pot (centre) and the left and right line-out connectors (left side). On the right side, at the same spacing, are two 6.5mm holes for panel mount switches that can be used to connect to the X400 jumpers for the headphone amp and mute function. Below the volume pot is a 6mm hole to allow a panel mount 3.5mm stereo socket to be fitted to connect to the X400 headphone out. Note; this mount is between the Pi and X400 boards and the cable from the socket to the X400 headphone jack runs between both boards.

The 'back' replaces the rear aluminium plate and has 6.5 mm holes at far left and far right for a pair of panel mount switches - one for the X400 speaker amp jumper and another to provide a switch for the power. There is an 8mm hole (2nd from right, top) for a DC power jack and four 7mm holes (centre) for speaker terminal posts. There is a hole for a panel mount USB 2.0 A socket and mounting screws. I use thumb screws on the back to provide some protection against accidental bumping of the toggle switches. If using the screws provided with the case, use the 'back-countersunk' file.

I've printed the bottom and back in PLA and the front in translucent PETG. The translucent front allows the LEDs on the Raspberry Pi to be seen to show power and network activity.

Previously, when the front plate was aluminium, I have used a 1mm hole on the centre line and 12mm below the centre of the headphone hole to allow the Pi's LEDs to be observed. This does not line up with the LEDs, but the polished side of the hole reflected the LED light and symmetry was maintained.

description.text:
This is an automatic fish feeder controlled by an Arduino. I tried several of the other automatic fish feeders listed online, and didn't have much luck, so I designed my own. It's designed to feed small food pellets, such as the Top Fin Betta Bits shown in the photos. The feeder arm contains a circular hole that is moved past the feeder bowl to meter out a small amount of food per actuation. If your fish need more (or less) simply change the code to update the feed interval. I'd recommend running a few cycles over a piece of paper to see if the mechanism feeds reliably for your chosen food, and to get the amount per feed cycle correct.

The "arm rev1" dispenses about 0.15 cm^3 of fish food per dose. I added another optional part, the "arm 6mm rev1" which dispenses about have of this, about 0.08 cm^3 per dose. I am trying some new ultra-fine ground guppy food, and it seems to work better to do a smaller dose, 2x per day. (which would require a slight tweak to the code as well)

There are various .STL "base" components included for different servo sizes. I ended up using a Turnigy TGY-53317S I had lying around, but pretty much any mid-sized servo will work. Your biggest limitation is how much current your servo will draw, and if your chosen Arduino can supply that much power. You may need to use some washers or similar to provide the right "standoff" distance between the base and servo, to get the correct alignment between the servo arm and the feeder arm.

I used a Arduino Pro Micro, but any will work. The Pro Micro's I have seem a bit flaky so I might recommend trying another flavor of Arduino, perhaps a Nano. I made a short cable out of a servo extension to allow easy servo swap outs. I connected the servo + lead to "RAW", - lead to "GND", and the signal lead to 3. (which needs to be a PWM output)

A sample Arduino code is in the download files for this thing. The text is also on my blog: http://andy-projects.blogspot.com/2017/09/arduino-controlled-3d-printed-automatic.html

I powered the pro-micro with a 1+ amp output USB wall wart. This seems to work fine and was reliable for a 1 week vacation.

When you assemble and set up the feeder, be sure to adjust the servo arm location and degrees of travel to get a result that functions properly and sits in the rest position without servo buzz.

And, as always, I've included the Solidworks files for your re-mixing fun.

UPDATES:
2017.11.19: Added "arm 6mm rev1" to add a smaller, 0.08cm^3 dose per feeding.

comments.author: printenac

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback. However, this system doesn't actually dump the entire bowl in one shot. The arm has a hole in it with a controlled volume- it only dispenses this controlled volume each cycle. If you need more than this small volume you could repeat the dispense cycle as many times as needed. The single cycle dispense volume is approximately 22 granules of the Betta Bits food shown in the picture. The bowl has enough volume to dispense at least 10 days's worth of food, using one cycle per day.

print_settings.Notes:: I recommend printing the endpieces flat -- the round holes for the rods will probably have a bit of play, as I made them 4.32mm, and printing on the side seems to ensure those stay pretty close to that.  Printing the midpieces upright will not only make the set stronger against forces in strange directions (with the layers facing the perpendicular direction from the endpiece), but also if you have any Z wobble or you squish your plastic down to the print bed, that will make the holes a little narrower, and reduce any rod wobbling you might have.  (In fact, I've had to cherry-pick my skewers to fit in the mid-pieces, so they may well go from 4.32mm to under 4mm holes on my printer...)
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
I started out printing KrisFab's design, but I wanted to use large rubber bands to have elasticity to hold in the pieces of music. When I glued the pieces together, they snapped, so I tried printing them thicker, with similar results. I don't blame the design, I blame my printer's condition ;) But anyway, I needed to have something easier for my machine to print a bunch of for a choir. Print two endpieces and one (optional) midpiece, add long rubber bands and rods, and you're done. I can print 8 sets at once (16 endpieces and 8 mid-pieces) on my 200x200mm bed. It takes forever (like, 10 hours), but they came out nicely.

I used 4mm rods for this design (approximately 10 inches long), with #117b rubber bands. I used bamboo skewers for the rods, but I may switch them for something with a bit more rigidity over time. Other than cutting the rods down to size, there isn't much post-printing that's needed to be done to be able to make use of this one.

In reality, don't even worry about the diameter of the rods, as long as they fit -- the more important thing is that they're the right length (just about 10 inches), and they provide rigidity. 1/8" steel rods will probably do the trick just fine (I'm considering picking some up to test). Even if one is markedly shorter than the other (like, half an inch different), the holes in the endpieces are over an inch long, so one rod might rattle around, but it will keep the other basically aligned anyway.

UPDATE: I made a smaller midpiece, as its purpose is mainly to just align the rods. I think it looks better, and it prints much faster now as well. Printed 16 of the midpieces standing up in a few hours.

UPDATE 2: I made an endpiece that adds some rounding to the various holes and to the sides (...endpiece_chamfered_inner.stl). I've found that this one prints more nicely for me, as I tend to press down the plastic a bit too much on the build plate. I can get my putty knife under the side and pry these off a lot easier. Hope it helps others out there, too.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.24mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

You probably don't need 25% infill, but I wanted these to be exceedingly rigid. I've been having issues with layer adhesion lately, so I just wanted to err on the side of caution and give it more locations where the layers are connected. I also was printing with 0.28mm layers, which was probably a mistake.

I recommend printing the endpieces flat -- the round holes for the rods will probably have a bit of play, as I made them 4.32mm, and printing on the side seems to ensure those stay pretty close to that. Printing the midpieces upright will not only make the set stronger against forces in strange directions (with the layers facing the perpendicular direction from the endpiece), but also if you have any Z wobble or you squish your plastic down to the print bed, that will make the holes a little narrower, and reduce any rod wobbling you might have. (In fact, I've had to cherry-pick my skewers to fit in the mid-pieces, so they may well go from 4.32mm to under 4mm holes on my printer...)

description.text:
This is a case for the Protractor Proximity Sensor. Not only does it keep the Protractor safe, it also helps shield the sensor from ambient light to maximize its usable range. This should be made from a black material to minimize reflections. It is better to not do any post-processing - leave the finish rough as this will help minimize light reflections. It is recommended to fine tune wall thickness in the attached OpenSCAD file to work best with your printer setup. The case shown in the picture was printed at Shapeways using PLA, and the model should work well for any FDM printer.

The Protractor is a proximity sensor that tells you the angle to nearby objects and open pathways. It is super useful for robotic applications such as Mini Sumo, Bulldozer, Object Collection, Obstacle Avoidance, Maze Solving, and many more.

Learn more about the Protractor Proximity Sensor at http://www.robogao.com/protractor
It's very simple and works.

description.text:
As great as my HIVE - Stackable Hex Drawers are, they don't hold a whole lot in the drawers and the complex printing movements add a lot of time. I tried to fix this with my Modular Drawers. But these modules did not interlock. This is the interlocking version of my Modular Drawers 1.0

Modular Drawers 2.0 offers a sleek design free of complex print movements, decreasing print time while increasing storage volume. The dimensions are: 85 mm x 85 mm x 100 mm providing more than enough space to hold screws, capacitors, and other common small components.

Like this design? Please consider helping me replace filament

The pictures are renders but tolerances have been accounted for. I printed a few modules but not the drawers yet.

Here is the Ferrofluid Vase from the renders

More Modular Drawer Systems
  • The HIVE - Stackable Hex Drawers (Interlocking)
  • Modular Drawers 1.0 (Stackable)
  • Modular Hex Drawers (Stackable)
  • Economical Drawers (Not modular)
Find me on:

Printer:

Ender 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200-400

Infill:

0-5%

Notes:
  • The drawers should fit inside the modules as is. It doesn't hurt to scale the modules to 101% and drawers remain at 100% (or drawers to 99% and modules 100%)
  • Print speed can be increased
  • Lower resolutions will print faster but may affect fit between slots and rails. If you have a problem with fit at lower res please tell me and I will upload a low res high speed module
  • I recommend printing with 5% infill
  • Combing cuts the time in half

description.text:
Model of Rick C-137's 9 gauge plasma pistol (and the slightly different, "fake" version) from Rick and Morty S03E01 ("The Rickshank Redemption") and other episodes.

There are two versions of the main body: one that's completely hollow, and one with a structure inside it designed to reduce the amount of support material needed (select "Supports: Everywhere" in Cura, or the equivalent in your other slicer of choice). There's also an optional part that can be helpful in aligning the endcap on the rear of the main body.

The model is split into sections for best print quality, and for making painting a bit easier. The parts of the barrel screw together, and are numbered in order (from the body to the muzzle). The finished barrel also screws into the main body.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.12mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I used the "Main Body with Support reducer" version, with supports set to "Everywhere" (not just from the buildplate).

The barrel parts don't really need supports, but they are highly recommended for the body, endcap, and handle halves.

Smoothing

It's highly recommended to smooth the model for best results. I sprayed it with a high-build filler primer, then sanded that down with successively finer grits. Then I glued the halves of the handle together using a clear two-part epoxy (making sure to put the trigger in the appropriate space first), and the endcaps to the main bodies (using the optional "Endcap Alignment Part"), then filled in the seams with JB-Weld epoxy, waited for them to dry, and smoothed the seams out.

Painting

I used Alclad II lacquers. First I put down a base layer of their gloss black base coat, then various metallic colors (Gunmetal, Steel, Aircraft Aluminum, and Silver Candy Base).

The Silver Candy Base parts were then tinted using their candy colors: a mixture of 2:1 red and violet for the redder parts, and 1:1 electric blue and violet for the bluer parts.

I mixed some UV-reactive pink pigments with white Testors enamel paint for the details on the handle and the slide.

Gluing

I used a clear two-part epoxy to glue the handle to the body.

Attaching the slide

I placed the slide top side down on a cutting mat on the floor. I then folded two pieces of wax paper and laid them along the inside of each side. I put the rest of the pistol upside down between the folded halves of wax paper, and pressed straight down until it clicked into place. I then carefully removed the wax paper.

(The wax paper was to prevent the inside of the slide from scratching the paint on the body. It's a very tight fit, but should allow the slide to move freely without coming loose.)

Secret Message

On a piece of masking tape, write the secret message from Rick to Morty, and affix it to the appropriate side on Morty's gun.

I modeled the pistol in Blender, based on various frame grabs from the episode. The most useful was a shot of Rick holding it in almost a perfect side view, which was instrumental in determining the proper dimensional relationships.

At least for that shot; since it was hand-drawn, and not a cel-shaded 3D model, the proportions varied quite a bit from shot to shot.

After the basic shape was finished, I split it into parts to avoid overhangs, in order to get the best print quality, and also to aid in painting.

title: CR-10 Dial Indicator Mount for X-Axis Rail

description.text:
This is a simple Dial Indicator Mount that slides over the x-axis extrusion. Allows bed leveling from an auto-home position with no need for g-code setup routines.

  1. Auto-home the print head and shut off machine.
  2. Level the first corner of the bed.
  3. Slide the dial indicator mount over the x-axis rail and position it over the leveled area. (Be careful not to pinch the lower x-axis belt when sliding the indicator mount over the rail.)
  4. Zero the indicator in the leveled area.
  5. Move indicator mount and print bed to level the other three corners.
  6. Slide mount off rail and you are ready to print.

Printer:

Hictop CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

50%

comments.text: I printed this, but it did not fit my dial indicator I bought from Aliexpress. The hole position is different and mine has a raised surface around the base of the hook / attachment point.
comments.author: derbythedog

comments.text:
Seems to work pretty well for a quick dirty fix.
It slides over the rail fairly snugly but loose enough to slide left and right. You just have to watch that because its friction fit it can still have a small amount of play once installed...I would say it gives a fairly good idea of how level the bed is within 0.01mm - 0.03mm but the weight of the dial indicator, the spring action of the probe pushing back up and the x axis belt rubbing against it can all affect the measurement so you just need to make sure you take your measurement the same way for all corners.

title: The Kube - ESP8266 NodeMCU DHT22 Local/Remote OLED Temperature/Humidity Sensor

description.text:
Check out my YouTube channel https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC82xXciVxsQKthONKeYbhnw for how to videos about 3d modeling, printing and home automation

SEE BELOW FOR BUILD INSTRUCTIONS

This project is my homemade/DIY temperature/humidity sensor, based on the NodeMCU ESP8266, and a DHT22 sensor. It uses a custom-made breakout board for the NodeMCU/DHT I designed in Eagle (available at PCBWay: https://goo.gl/U2fY7y). The breakout board allows me to easily connect things like an OLED screen (for local display), motion sensors or WS2812 RGB LED strings (for LED strip control). The NodeMCU itself runs code I wrote to get the temp/humidty/motion inputs, and publish them via MQTT to my openHAB home automation system.

This enclosure was designed to make the whole setup look more pleasing to the (wife's) eye, rather than having random PCBs out around the house.

Design changes/features since original prototype (9/17/17):
-Thicker front/back walls (1mm->3mm, more sturdy and will prevent PCB from shifting forward/back)
-Thicker hole for the USB connector (to allow the cable's USB connector housing to clear)
-Modified OLED mounting holes to posts so no hardware required (just stick the OLED screen on and hot glue in place)
-Added 2mm edges on the bottom cover front/back, to completely cover the PCB (and hold it better in place)
-Narrowed down OLED screen window to only show visible screen
-Slightly moved screen closer to top wall and extended posts (melt to hold screen in place)
-Created a notch in the USB-side wall, to clear the NodeMCU board interference with wall (was preventing carrier board from sitting in the middle of its "channel").
-Chamfered the notch for easier 3d printing.
-Rounded the edges for a more aesthetic look.
-Corrected spacing of the mounting posts for the OLED display)
-Added bottom opening below USB connector (for the EXT connector on new breakout)
-Added louvers to match the DHT sensor's side/top openings (for better airflow/sensing)
-Added second version of the box, with diagonal louvers along both sides (originally for airflow, but with the calibration code change I made, they're purely aesthetic now)
-Uploaded new board/schematic file, for a new revision of the breakout board which I've ordered/tested (updated link to OSHPark as well). The new board supports both NodeMCU 0.9 as well as 1.0, and is better annotated, as I've learned to use Eagle a bit better.
-Counter-sunk holes on the bottom cover to hide screw heads and make box flat on the wall
-Removed interference with FLASH/RST buttons on NodeMCU v2 boards and the internal wall of the enclosure.

Code (available at https://github.com/bkpsu/NodeMCU-Home-Automation-Sensor):
-Added new config option for LOCAL, to disable Wifi/MQTT connectivity for local sensor display only
-Added temp/humidity linear offsets, for calibration (I've noticed different batches of my DHT22 sensors have wildly varied offsets, but the offsets appear to be linear). I've calibrated them by placing the sensors next to my main thermostat for a few days. They appear to track very well with the applied offsets.

12/29/2017 Update
-Added v1.1 of the .brd and .sch files, incorporating the 3.3/5v selector jumper (i.e. selecting which of those voltages is sourced for the EXTernal sensor power rail). I've tested this version of the board (ordered from OSHPark) and I've also placed an order at PCBWay to try out a cheaper PCB service.

This design is COMPLETE

Note The links in the parts list below are to the parts I used/ordered for my sensors. They are affiliate links, so if you feel like supporting me and my designs, please go ahead and use them to get your parts. Thank you and enjoy!

Check out my (mostly functional) 3D designs - (https://www.thingiverse.com/bkpsu/designs) ! If you like them and want to support my projects, use one of the links below when you're planning to buy anything from these sites (it won't cost you anything extra!). Thank you in advance!

Banggood: https://goo.gl/uXGg84
AliExpress: https://goo.gl/KRNurW
Amazon: https://goo.gl/nWhmjJ

How to build sensor

Parts List (Affiliate links to parts I've used/tested):
-this enclosure
-OLED screen (http://amzn.to/2xR4iQP)
-NodeMCU breakout board (https://goo.gl/U2fY7y)
-NodeMCU ESP8266 dev board v0.9 ($6 & Prime from Amazon: http://amzn.to/2hd6RJk, $3 from AliExpress: https://goo.gl/fQGwBN) or 1.0 (http://amzn.to/2ymAkak).
-DHT-22 sensor (http://amzn.to/2ymmODK)
-headers (http://amzn.to/2fNe81C)
-solid hook-up wire, 22awg (http://amzn.to/2xbTaAW)

Initial build

  1. Print enclosure and cover
  2. Solder left/right inner headers onto the OSHPark carrier board (15 pins each)
  3. Solder DHT22 sensor onto board, with openings facing out
  4. Stick NodeMCU board onto carrier board, USB connector facing opposite from DHT22
  5. De-pin OLED screen (cut the black plastic holding pins together, remove pins one by one) <- alternatively, you can use breadboard wires (http://amzn.to/2fDGqeJ) with connectors on each end if you don't want to de-pin, but you'll have to bend the OLED screen pins to the side.
  6. Cut seven (7) short (~2 inch) lengths of hook-up wire and strip on each end.
  7. Connect/solder OLED screen to carrier board as follows:

For SPI OLED:

Board Wire Color OLED
3v3 Red VCC
Gnd Black Gnd
D10 Orange Res
D9 Gray DC
D8 White CS
D7 Yellow D1
D5 Brown D0

For I2C OLED:

Board Wire Color OLED
3v3 Red VCC
Gnd Black Gnd
D10 Yellow SCL
D9 Brown SDA

Final Assembly:

  1. Stick OLED screen onto mounting posts (ensuring the screen is within the enclosure opening) and use a soldering iron to melt the posts over it.
  2. Put NodeMCU carrier board in, ensuring it fits snugly (DHT sensor is tightly within its opening, USB connector is visible)
  3. Put enclosure cover on, and secure with small screws (or glue in place)
  4. Program sensor. I've posted my code here: https://github.com/bkpsu/NodeMCU-Home-Automation-Sensor
Fusion 360 for the enclosure, Eagle CAD for the circuit/PCB

A good project to introduce Arduino environment, sensor programming, 3d modelling/printing, PCB design, and DIY/maker community (GitHub, Thingiverse, Fusion, etc.). Successful completion results in a fun project with a take-home end product (finished sensor ready to mount on a wall).

• Download 3d STL files and print the enclosure
  • Solder connections/boards in accordance with above procedure
  • Complete assembly
  • Complete programming and test.
    • Can be split into multiple lessons/sub projects.
Parts list above.

comments.text: Have you tested your temperatures with/without the case? I'm finding my readings are 3-5°C higher once I install everything in the case, I'm guessing the ESP is warming it all up slightly. I might try the louvred version and see if it's any different.
comments.author: kieranc

comments.text: Yes, I have and found out the same! (I mentioned it in one of my updates here and on Github) - basically, when I'm running the ESP always on vs deepsleep, the ESP temperature definitely seems to affect the DHT22 sensor measurement (or perhaps it's just the natural offset of an uncalibrated DHT sensor). I noticed the offset was linear (at least for the temperature range I need, ~60-80 *F), so I put in a manual calibration offset into my code. To find the offset, I left the sensors on in the same room as my HVAC thermostat and logged measurements over the course of a few days. Looking at the resulting graph, I could easily calculate the offset required to bring the sensor's temperature in line with the thermostat, which is what I need these to be calibrated to, anyway, since I'm trying to see how the HVAC system is heating/cooling the different rooms in my house better or worse.
